Pocantico Hills CSD added 32 new photos.
July 20 at 4:29 PM ·

School may be out for the summer, but our Poco campus is bustling with activity! We’re welcoming visitors every day to our amazing pool, where we have temperature checks and practice social distancing. Our childcare program for children of essential workers and first responders continues each weekday. Our employees and visitors are wearing masks, getting their temperatures taken, and socially distancing from one another when possible. Near the pool, our custodians have placed the paving blocks our eighth-grade graduates created with their hand prints under a recently planted red maple tree.

As we develop our plans for reopening school safely, we have outfitted our front desk and nearby offices with plexiglass shields, and we have generous amounts of hand sanitizer available throughout the school. In the middle school wing, workers are installing new floors. Our custodians are cleaning and sanitizing classrooms and other spaces, and we are taking additional steps to ensure the health and safety of our students, staff and community.

Pocantico Hills CSD added 159 new photos.
June 18 at 2:03 PM ·

Yesterday was a great day for a parade at Pocantico! Eighth-graders first visited campus around 10:30 a.m. to make handprints and etch their names in aluminum foil pans filled with cement. The paving blocks will be featured at the base of a newly planted red maple tree on campus. Graduate John Preiser proposed the idea of “sealing” students’ hands on campus since they have been under a quarantine.

At 11:45 a.m., graduates and their families lined up in a parking lot on Route 117. The Mount Pleasant Police Department, the Pocantico Hills Fire Department and two Poco school buses escorted everyone down Route 448. Staff members and families from the community lined up in front of the school to cheer on the parade as it passed. The cars drove down past the firehouse before looping back to campus. They drove through the bus circle for a “graduation drive-out” to wish the 26 eighth-graders good luck in high school.
Many thanks to the Mount Pleasant Police

Department and the Pocantico Hills Fire Department for their help in putting the parade together!

Pre-kindergarteners continue to focus on one letter each week while the school building is closed. They follow a daily plan around the letter, including a book activity with discussion questions, and activities to develop their writing, fine/gross motor skills and math, teacher Tracy Carrigan said.

Some activities during the letter E week April 20-24 were to make something beautiful out of recyclables and create an Earth Day poster about how they would help the Earth. Children learned about elephants and were asked to design their own elephant. One student did a great job with rocks.

Ms. Carrigan said she also encourages students to take nature walks, get exercise outside and engage in purposeful play.

While students, teachers and administrative staff were off Saturday, it was all hands on deck for the school’s cleaning staff. The extensive sanitizing regime is a precautionary measure due to coronavirus.

Director of Facilities Donald Booth led a team of a dozen people who spent the day wiping down all surfaces – from door handles and windows to gym lockers, furniture and garbage cans. Mr. Booth followed up with an electrostatic spray cleaner. The state-of-the-art equipment sprays an electrostatically charged mist evenly onto all surfaces. Because of the charge, the particles in the chlorine and water solution cling to all surfaces.

“Everybody I could get I grabbed,” Mr. Booth said. “Every square inch of the building gets wiped down, disinfected and on top of that, we come along and spray every square inch of the building with an electrostatic sprayer.”

February 20 at 2:11 PM ·

As part of our celebration of Black History Month, we welcomed Chef Giovanni D’Amour Green of Break Bread Not Hearts to work with middle school students for four days. The entrepreneur and educator held hands-on cooking sessions that focused on plant-based meals. He also shared some of his poetry.

At the beginning of each class, Chef Green asked students to tell him their name, favorite food, family heritage and a fun fact about themselves. When they finished, he went down the line and recited everyone’s name correctly.

In the Feb. 13 sessions, Chef Green and students cooked pancakes, scrambled eggs and home fries made with purple potatoes, chickpeas, green peppers and corn. He shared with children that love is a crucial ingredient in all recipes, and that cooking is a great way to build community.

Also that day, he shared his recipes with the cafeteria staff and set the menu for lunch: grilled cheese; All Yum Autumn Soup; and Sweet Potato, Black-Eyed Pea and Roasted Corn Salad with Grapes.

Thank you, Chef Green, for a great educational experience!

Thank you to everyone who attended and participated in One World Evening February 13! This was the second year in a row the Diversity Committee sponsored the event.

The evening started with student performances that included taekwondo, Indian dancing, playing the Chinese harp and African dancing. Afterward, attendees moved from the auditorium to the gymnasium, where they sampled food from many cultures and tried arts and crafts such as origami, sand art and calligraphy.

In a school of about 320 students, families’ cultural roots span more than 100 countries, Principal Adam Brown said. “This is a night to truly celebrate each other, our diversity, our cultural roots and just appreciate and enjoy and learn from each other and this most wonderful way,” he said.

The class that raises the most money wins a pizza party.

Children, families and staff members celebrated the customs, traditions and food of other cultures during the recent “One World Evening."

The event began with three student performances in the auditorium: Hindu sun salutations, Irish step dance and a traditional Colombian dance.

Visitors then took the “One World Walk” in the cafeteria and viewed displays created by different families. Some of the countries represented were Colombia, Chile, Egypt, Israel, Poland, China, Ukraine, Nigeria and Ecuador.

Many families brought traditional food and drink, such as chai tea, samosas, kielbasa, empanadas, sushi and pierogi. They displayed pictures of their countries, dressed in clothing that is worn there and shared some of their traditions, such as making paper lanterns, painting characters and origami.

The school's Diversity Committee organized the event, which was a great success. Thanks to everyone who participated and attended!

Families are invited to attend the district’s second Family Workshop, which starts at 7 p.m. tomorrow (February 26). The topic is effective communication, which was selected based on the results of the last community survey.

Specifically, the workshop will focus on the interpersonal skills taught in the dialectical behavior therapy acronym DEAR MAN, which stands for Describe, Express, Assert, Reinforce, be Mindful, Appear confident and Negotiate. Dialectical Behavior Therapy teaches interpersonal skills, mindfulness, emotion regulation and distress tolerance.

The school’s Therapeutic Support Program staff will facilitate the event in collaboration with the PTA. The TSP team includes Dr. Glenn Pollack, school psychologist; guidance counselors Jim McVeigh and Sara Sonne; and Therapeutic Support Center teacher Mario Suarez.

We are looking forward to a fun and informative evening, and hope to see as many of you there as possible! To RSVP and provide feedback, visit https://bit.ly/2BSb8sp.

Children’s book author Aisha Saeed visited the school Nov. 6 as part of the Global Read Aloud event. “Amal Unbound,” Ms. Saeed’s second book, is about a Pakistani girl who has to leave school to help out her family at home. After a run-in with a powerful member of the community, she is forced into indentured servitude to pay off a family debt.

Ms. Saeed, who is Pakistani-American, said she is inspired by young people’s courage, particularly that of Malala Yousafzai, a young Pakistani advocate for girls’ and women’s education.

“There’s so much bravery that all of us have within us that we can do to change the world, whether it’s in huge ways like Malala, who won a Nobel Peace Prize, or small ways just in our community,” the author said.

Ms. Saeed spoke with several classes and ate a special lunch with students that Chef Kassie Arcate prepared. She also signed copies of her book.

In preparation for the event, Jolene Morotti’s art students cut out tracings of their hands and drew henna-style designs on them. Ms. Morotti created a bulletin board with them.

Pocantico’s D.A.R.E. officers from the Mount Pleasant Police Department offered the following tips during a Halloween safety presentation this week:
-- Only go to houses that have any lights on.
-- Use flashlights and/or Glow Sticks and glow-in-the-dark necklaces, bracelets and pins. Make sure cell phones are charged.
-- Parents and guardians should supervise young children as they go trick or treating.
-- Never enter someone’s home.
-- Don’t eat any candy until you get home and your parents or guardians check it.
-- Children and parents should wear reflective clothing if possible.
-- Use sidewalks when possible and cross streets at crosswalks and corners. Don’t walk in the middle of the street.
-- Wear comfortable shoes. Be careful walking up and down steps if you have a long costume. Children should make sure they can see well out of masks; otherwise they should be adjusted.
-- Be respectful of the homeowners and their property. Toilet papering someone’s home or throwing eggs at a car are acts of criminal mischief.

There are only a few hours left until eighth-graders graduate from Pocantico Hills, and they have been celebrating. Two stretch limousines picked them up at school this week and drove them to a class celebration at Grand Prix. At the entertainment center, DJ Kevin spun the tunes while the eighth-graders bowled, ate, danced and hit the arcade. The class held two car washes and sold products through Yankee Candle during the school year to offset the cost of the party. Many of the students have been at Pocantico since pre-kindergarten, and the party marked the culmination of their elementary and middle school experiences.

On Wednesday afternoon, the whole school participated in “Clap Out.” Eighth-graders donned their caps and gowns and paraded around the school as younger students, teachers and staff clapped and wished them well in high school. Congratulations to all the graduates!

The visit was one of the many highlights of the annual event. Others included meeting police K-9 dogs and their human partners, climbing into a tractor from Stone Barns, and watching the Elmsford Fire Department’s “Tower of Power” ladder platform extend 100 feet above the ground.
